title: Here are the US exports that could get slapped with retaliation by other countries
text: Let friends in your social network know what you are reading about Facebook Email Here are the U.S. exports that could get slapped with retaliation by other countries Countries are widely expected to respond with countermeasures to Washington's proposed tariffs on foreign steel and aluminum imports Post to Facebook Here are the U.S. exports that could get slapped with retaliation by other countries Countries are widely expected to respond with countermeasures to Washington's proposed tariffs on foreign steel and aluminum imports Check out this story on USATODAY.com: https://usat.ly/2oJW5tG Cancel Send A link has been sent to your friend's email address. Posted! A link has been posted to your Facebook feed. 2 To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Here are the U.S. exports that could get slapped with retaliation by other countries Nyshka Chandran, CNBC Published 9:43 a.m. ET March 2, 2018 | Updated 9:44 a.m. ET March 2, 2018 CLOSE U.S. President Donald Trump said on Thursday the United States would impose tariffs of 25 percent on steel imports and 10 percent on imported aluminum, starting next week. Rough Cut (no reporter narration). Video provided by Reuters Newslook Rolled aluminum products in a warehouse. (Photo: Getty Images) CONNECT 2 COMMENT EMAIL MORE President Donald Trump's tariffs on steel and aluminum imports has triggered sharp criticism from the international community, begging the question of how the world will react. It's still too early to tell how other governments may respond — so far, Canada and the European Union have promised strong countermeasures but didn't provide details. If the administration applies its tariffs to all steel and aluminum exports — as opposed to cherry-picking countries to punish — there are five nations that will suffer the most. Brazil , Canada and South Korea were the three largest suppliers of steel to the U.S. last year, according to data from IHS. Canada, Russia and the U.A.E. were the three largest suppliers of aluminum in 2016. Cornell University Professor Eswar Prasad told CNBC that countries may hit back in the form of "surgical strikes," meaning they may choose to target specific U.S. products. For that reason, it's worth looking at what the United States is selling to the nations most at risk from Trump's tariffs.
